quoteFirst: Thus, one of his earliest acts when he obtained the control in Kyoto was to appoint officials for impartially administering justice, to reduce the citizens' taxes; to succour widows and orphans, and to extend to all the blessings of security and tranquillity. In 1572, we find him sending messengers to the provinces with instructions to put in hand the making of roads having a width of from
quoteLast: feet; to set up milestones and plant trees along these roads; to build bridges; to remove barriers, and generally to facilitate communications.
title: A history of the Japanese people
author: Brinkley, F. (Frank), 1841-1912; Kikuchi, Dairoku, 1855-1917
